Authors:
Valeria B Ponizovskaya, Alexey Grum-Grzhimaylo, Marina L.
Georgieva, Lyudmila Yu. KOKAEVA, Elena N. Bilanenko
Title:
Lecanicillium gracile (Cordycipitaceae), a new species
isolated from mineral building materials
Keywords:
biodeterioration, Lecanicillium, limestone, new species,
plaster, taxonomy
Abstract:
We report abundant lecanicillia fungi isolated from
deteriorated limestone and plaster in interiors of cultural heritage
sites in Russia. The phylogenetic analysis of ITS rDNA and TEF1a
sequences coupled with morphological observations showed one of the
Lecanicillium isolates as a new species, which we describe here as
Lecanicillium gracile sp. nov. Lecanicillium gracile is morphologically
similar to the closely related species, such as L. coprophilum, L.
restrictum and L. testudineum, but it differs from them by the ability
to produce phialides secondarily on the preceeding phialides. Another
abundant Lecanicillium isolates grouped with the other two recently
described lecanicillia species, namely L. testudineum and L.
coprophilum. Hence, we leave those isolates unidentified. A third
species isolated from deteriorated limestone and plaster in interiors
was identified as Parengyodontium album, which is phylogenetically close
to Lecanicillium and produces zigzag-shaped tips of conidiogenous cells.
Given high abundance of the isolated species and their physiological
traits, we conclude that they are involved in deterioration of stone
materials in interiors of cultural heritage and deserve attention during
restoration works.
